instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2338: What is A2338? A2338 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2020 M1, Mid 2022 M2 with EMC 8162, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02020, 820-02773..
definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00392: What is 820-00392? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S2: What is PP3V3_S2? PP3V3_S2 is a typo of PP3V3_S3.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - MacBook Pro M1) - Battery not recognized / No keyboard backlight
threads.message:
Hi,

I have a MacBook Pro M1 which doesn't recognize the battery (0% - Cross Icon).

<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_AON</SIGNAL> (with charger and battery connected) = 11.96V
<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_AON</SIGNAL> (without charger and battery connected) = 1.4V
<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_AON_CHRG_REG</SIGNAL> = 11.96V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_AON_CHRG_R</SIGNAL> = 20V

I assume the board is fine because both MOSFETs (<TRANSISTOR>Q5230</TRANSISTOR>/40) are testing good.

Note:
- I can successfully boot into macOS (fan is going high due of the not detected battery).
- At the first boot it crashes and then boots again into the OS.
- Sadly I don't have another battery for testing .... :/
- No battery information available under "System Report" (Cell version, hardware version, firmware etc.)
- Battery voltage (+/-) is 2.1V, pretty low.

Battery board (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00392</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A):
- Two PINs (red arrow) are connected to each pad of the flex, is that normal? (at least I measured "continuity" with the multimeter)
(Check attachment)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - MacBook Pro M1) - Battery not recognized / No keyboard backlight
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_AON</SIGNAL> (without charger and battery connected) = 1.4V"
Looks like bad battery.

Make short on <RESISTOR>R5155</RESISTOR> pads and check battery voltage again.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.laptopu.ro/product/professional-laptop-battery-analyzer-nlba1/[/URL]
Good to have it in the service; the best manner to properly diagnose the batteries.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - MacBook Pro M1) - Battery not recognized / No keyboard backlight
threads.message:
Same voltage.

If I need to replace the battery ... which do you recommend? (Location: Europe)

Note: The battery board was a little bit corroded at F400 area. (Fuse is OK)

Edit: Why is the keyboard backlight not working?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - MacBook Pro M1) - Battery not recognized / No keyboard backlight
threads.message:
Check if ALS works properly.
If not, KB backlight is disabled.

No idea where can you buy good batteries in your area...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - MacBook Pro M1) - Battery not recognized / No keyboard backlight
threads.message:
ALS is working and KB backlight can be adjusted via OS (but can't say anything on the keyboard - have tested it in a dark area)

I have found out that "RT046" was blown, replaced it now I have 5.1V on "<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_KBDLED</SIGNAL>" - still no backlight. (KB brightness is set to 100%)

Bad keyboard backlight?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - MacBook Pro M1) - Battery not recognized / No keyboard backlight
threads.message:
RT046 should got burnt because of KB backlight.
Test with known good one.
Be sure DP900 is not shorted A-K first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - MacBook Pro M1) - Battery not recognized / No keyboard backlight
threads.message:
I have replaced the kb backlight and battery sadly ... both are still not working … any idea, what else I can check?

Edit: DP900 is fine.

Edit2: I noticed when turning on the MBP after 2-3 seconds it crashes and then it boots up again. (I can login etc.)
Still strange why it is crashing at the start up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - MacBook Pro M1) - Battery not recognized / No keyboard backlight
threads.message: Save data and try DFU restore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - MacBook Pro M1) - Battery not recognized / No keyboard backlight
threads.message:
it always ends with:
[MEDIA=imgur]a/0phmPas[/MEDIA]

edit: Now I was able to restore (repair) it but the issues like high fan speed, no battery detected and no ob backlight is still present.

What else could be the issue? I mean I have successfully restored the device.

edit2: I found the reason why the battery is not detected … shame on me that I haven’t that checked first.

[MEDIA=imgur]a/bRBbQxD[/MEDIA]

I will order a new cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - MacBook Pro M1) - Battery not recognized / No keyboard backlight
threads.message:
New cable installed ... battery is now detected and im able to charge it.

Still don't know why the KB isn't working, any idea?

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_KBDLED_CONN</SIGNAL> = 5.1V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM_KEYB_3V3</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_S2</SIGNAL> = 1.25V
<SIGNAL>KBD_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> = 0V

(I have set it in macOS to max. brightness)

So the MacBook does recognize the kb backlight because otherwise I wouldn't see the "brightness" control.
Is the PWM signal required to adjust the brightness? (Gets generated from the M1?)

Edit: Fixed UP900 was bad, KB backlight is now working.
